size: Height: up to 3.3 m at the shoulder; Weight: 4,500-6,800 kg.
habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and woodlands across sub-Saharan Africa.
funFact: Matriarch-led herds communicate using infrasonic rumbles that travel for kilometers.

size: Length: 24-30 m; Weight: up to 180 metric tons.
habitat: Pelagic waters of all major oceans, migrating seasonally between feeding and breeding grounds.
funFact: Its heart is roughly the size of a compact car and beats only a few times per minute while diving.

lifeExpectancy: 20 years in the wild and up to 30 years with expert care.
habitat: Cool temperate bamboo forests in China's Sichuan, Shaanxi, and Gansu provinces.
funFact: A panda's pseudo-thumb is an enlarged wrist bone that lets it deftly strip bamboo stalks.

size: Length: 2.7-3.1 m including tail; Weight: 180-260 kg for males.
habitat: Mangroves, grasslands, and forests across India, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Bhutan.
funFact: Each tiger's stripe pattern is unique, working like a fingerprint when stalking prey through cover.

size: Length: 1.2-1.6 m; Weight: 30-50 kg depending on region.
habitat: Forests, tundra, deserts, and mountains across North America and Eurasia.
funFact: Wolves' howls can carry over 10 km, coordinating pack members when hunting or defending territory.

size: Length: 2.4-3 m; Weight: 350-600 kg for males.
habitat: Arctic sea ice, coastal fjords, and islands surrounding the North Pole.
funFact: Hollow, translucent fur and a thick blubber layer insulate polar bears even in minus 40°C storms.

size: Length: 60-85 cm; Weight: 4-15 kg depending on latitude.
habitat: Eucalyptus woodlands along Australia's eastern and southern coasts.
funFact: Koalas sleep up to 20 hours per day to conserve energy for digesting fibrous eucalyptus leaves.

size: Body length: 1.3-1.6 m; Weight: 55-90 kg for males.
habitat: Open plains, grasslands, and deserts across central Australia.
funFact: Powerful hind legs let males bound 9 m in a single leap while the tail works as a balancing third leg.

size: Arm span: up to 2.0 m; Weight: 35-80 kg.
habitat: Lowland tropical rainforests of Borneo.
funFact: Orangutans build a fresh nest of branches and leaves high in the canopy every evening.

habitat: Slow-moving rivers, lakes, and wetlands across sub-Saharan Africa.
funFact: Hippos secrete an orange 'blood sweat' that acts as both sunscreen and antibacterial protection.

size: Length: 1.7-2.5 m excluding tail; Weight: 150-250 kg for males.
habitat: Savannas and open woodlands across eastern and southern Africa.
funFact: Lions are the only truly social big cats, living in prides that cooperatively raise cubs.

habitat: Open grasslands and semi-arid plains of sub-Saharan Africa.
funFact: Semi-retractable claws and a flexible spine let cheetahs sprint over 100 km/h.

size: Height: 1.4-1.8 m standing; Weight: 120-195 kg for adult males.
habitat: Montane cloud forests of the Virunga Massif and Bwindi Impenetrable Forest.
funFact: They build fresh foliage nests on the ground every night after foraging.

habitat: High-altitude cliffs and alpine meadows across Central and South Asia.
funFact: A snow leopard's tail can be as long as its body and wraps around like a scarf for warmth.

size: Length: 75-110 cm including tail; Weight: 3-8 kg.
habitat: Tundra and pack ice regions across the circumpolar Arctic.
funFact: Its dense coat changes from brown in summer to white in winter for camouflage.

habitat: Freshwater streams, billabongs, and rivers of eastern Australia and Tasmania.
funFact: Male platypuses bear venomous ankle spurs delivering powerful defensive stings.

habitat: Coastal and offshore waters of temperate and tropical oceans worldwide.
funFact: Each dolphin develops a signature whistle that acts like a personal name.

habitat: Lowland rainforests from Honduras through northern Argentina.
funFact: Algae grow in its shaggy fur, providing camouflage and extra nutrients when groomed.

size: Length: 1.8-2.4 m including tail; Weight: 30-50 kg.
habitat: Savannas, wetlands, and tropical forests of Central and South America.
funFact: Its tongue can flick 160 times per minute to lap up ants and termites.

lifeExpectancy: 15 years in the wild and up to 30 in care.
habitat: Burrow systems in forests and heathlands of southeastern Australia.
funFact: Wombats produce cube-shaped scat that stacks neatly to mark territory.

habitat: Savannas, open woodlands, and scrublands of sub-Saharan Africa.
funFact: Packs share food by regurgitating meals for pups and injured members.

size: Height: up to 2.1 m at the shoulder; Weight: 380-700 kg.
habitat: Boreal forests, marshes, and tundra edges of northern North America and Eurasia.
funFact: Bulls regrow massive palmate antlers every year that can span wider than 1.8 m.

habitat: Prairies, plains, and river valleys across North America.
funFact: Despite their bulk, bison can pivot quickly and sprint up to 55 km/h.

habitat: Arid scrublands and savannas of southern Africa.
funFact: Groups take turns standing guard and use distinct alarm calls for different predators.

size: Length: 90-105 cm including tail; Weight: 3.5-8 kg.
habitat: Forests, farmlands, tundra edges, and urban fringes across the Northern Hemisphere.
funFact: Red foxes pinpoint prey beneath snow by listening for vibrations before making a high pounce.

size: Height: 1.5-2 m at the shoulder; Weight: 200-350 kg.
habitat: Dense understory of the Ituri rainforest in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
funFact: Its prehensile tongue is so long it can clean its eyelids and ears.

habitat: Warm coastal shallows, estuaries, rivers, and freshwater springs in the Caribbean and southeastern United States.
funFact: Manatees graze up to 10% of their body weight in seagrass daily to fuel their slow metabolism.

size: Length: 1.3-1.7 m; Weight: 65-100 kg for males.
habitat: Steep, rocky slopes above the treeline throughout the European Alps.
funFact: Males use their meter-long, ridged horns to spar on cliff edges during the rut.

habitat: Coastal heath, forests, and agricultural areas on the island of Tasmania.
funFact: It has the strongest bite force relative to body size among living mammals.

habitat: Cold Arctic waters around Canada, Greenland, Svalbard, and Russia.
funFact: Males grow a spiraled canine tooth up to 3 m long packed with sensory nerve endings.

habitat: Warm shallow reefs of the Indo-Pacific, living symbiotically among sea anemones.
funFact: All clownfish hatch as males; the dominant fish can change sex to become the breeding female.

habitat: Temperate coastal and offshore waters worldwide.
funFact: Great whites sense faint electrical fields using ampullae of Lorenzini to locate prey.

size: Length: commonly 10-12 m; Weight: up to 20 tonnes.
habitat: Tropical and warm-temperate oceans, frequenting plankton-rich surface waters.
funFact: Despite its size, it filter-feeds on plankton through a mouth wider than 1.5 m.

size: Length: up to 50 cm (20 in); Weight: around 3.5 kg (7.7 lb).
habitat: Slow rivers, floodplain lakes, and oxbow lagoons of the Amazon and Orinoco basins.
funFact: Schools shear chunks from prey with razor-edged, interlocking teeth, often attacking in coordinated bursts.

size: Length: 71-76 cm; Weight: 3.6-5.4 kg, larger in northern rivers.
lifeExpectancy: 4-6 years, with some surviving over a decade.
habitat: North Atlantic Ocean and the freshwater rivers used for spawning migrations.
funFact: Atlantic salmon use the Earth's magnetic field and scent cues to return to their natal streams.

habitat: Tropical Indo-Pacific reefs; introduced populations in the western Atlantic and Caribbean.
funFact: Venomous dorsal spines deliver a painful sting, and striped fins confuse would-be predators.

size: Wingspan: 4-7 m; Weight: up to 1,350 kg.
habitat: Open tropical and subtropical oceans, often at productive upwelling sites.
funFact: Manta rays make high leaps clear of the water during social and mating displays.

habitat: Seagrass beds, mangroves, and sheltered coastal reefs across the Indo-Pacific.
funFact: Male seahorses brood fertilized eggs in a pouch and give birth to miniature young.

size: Length: 3.5-6 m; Weight: up to 450 kg.
habitat: Warm coastal waters, continental shelves, and coral reefs in tropical and subtropical seas worldwide.
funFact: The wide cephalofoil acts like a wing, helping the shark pin stingrays to the seafloor before striking.

size: Length: typically 1.7-2.2 m (5.6-7.2 ft), reaching 4 m; Weight: up to 180 kg (400 lb).
habitat: Pelagic waters of temperate and tropical oceans, often following cool currents across entire basins.
funFact: Long, scythe-like pectoral fins and a streamlined body let blue sharks migrate thousands of kilometres between feeding and pupping grounds.

size: Length: 1.75-2.5 m; Weight: up to 20 kg.
habitat: Slow-moving rivers, floodplains, and swamps of the Amazon and Orinoco basins.
funFact: Specialized electric organs can discharge shocks exceeding 600 volts to stun prey.

habitat: Deep volcanic slopes off the Comoros Islands, South Africa, and Indonesia.
funFact: Thought extinct until 1938, coelacanths have limb-like fins that hint at early tetrapod evolution.

size: Length: 1.8-2.5 m; Weight: up to 2,200 kg.
lifeExpectancy: At least 10 years in the wild.
habitat: Temperate and tropical oceans, basking near the surface and diving for jellyfish.
funFact: A female sunfish can release more than 300 million eggs in a single spawning.

size: Length: up to 2.5 m (8.2 ft); Weight: can exceed 300 kg (660 lb).
habitat: Cold, deep waters of the North Atlantic continental shelf and slope.
funFact: Juveniles swim upright, but as they mature both eyes migrate to the right side and the fish lies flat on dark seafloors waiting for prey.

habitat: Shallow rice paddies, canals, and floodplains of Thailand and Cambodia.
funFact: Males build bubble nests on the water surface and guard the eggs inside.

habitat: North Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea, undertaking long-distance migrations.
funFact: Countercurrent circulation lets bluefin maintain body temperatures above ambient seawater.

habitat: Deep continental slopes worldwide, typically below 100 m.
funFact: It catapults its protrusible jaws forward to snare fish and squid in the deep sea.

size: Length: up to 20 cm for females; males are dwarf-sized.
habitat: Bathypelagic zones of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
funFact: Females lure prey with a glowing lure while tiny males fuse onto them for life.

habitat: Warm tropical and subtropical oceans near the surface.
funFact: They can glide over 200 m using enlarged pectoral fins to escape predators.

size: Length: commonly 61–76 cm; Weight: up to 40 kg in older individuals.
lifeExpectancy: Up to 25 years in cold northern waters.
habitat: North Atlantic continental shelves, from Greenland and the Barents Sea to Cape Hatteras.
funFact: Atlantic cod form immense winter spawning aggregations that historically drew fleets to Newfoundland and Iceland.

habitat: Cold freshwater rivers, lakes, and coastal streams in North America; widely introduced elsewhere.
funFact: Some populations go to sea as steelhead before returning to their natal rivers to spawn.

size: Length: 4-7 m; Weight: up to 1,000 kg.
habitat: Deep, cold waters of the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.
funFact: Greenland sharks grow less than 1 cm per year and are among the longest-lived vertebrates.

lifeExpectancy: Around 15 years in the wild and decades in captivity.
habitat: Coral reefs and lagoon drop-offs throughout the Indo-Pacific from East Africa to Polynesia.
funFact: Juveniles wear concentric blue-and-white rings that transform into bold yellow and sapphire stripes as adults.

size: Length: 2-3 m; Weight: up to 150 kg.
habitat: Slow-moving rivers and large lakes across Europe and western Asia.
funFact: Wels catfish gulp air at the surface to survive in oxygen-poor waters and occasionally ambush birds.

habitat: Shallow, slow-moving streams and rice paddies across the Ganges-Brahmaputra basin of South Asia.
funFact: Transparent embryos and rapid development make the zebra danio a cornerstone of vertebrate genetics and regenerative research.

size: Length: 1-2 m; Weight: up to 200 kg.
habitat: Large freshwater lakes and rivers across sub-Saharan Africa, notably Lake Victoria.
funFact: Juveniles school in shallow bays while adults become solitary ambush predators.

habitat: Warm and temperate sections of the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific Oceans.
funFact: Sailfish can surge over 100 km/h, folding their dorsal fin to cut drag.

size: Length: 7-9 m; Weight: up to 5,200 kg.
habitat: Temperate coastal waters, often skim-feeding at the surface for plankton.
funFact: It filters about 2,000 liters of seawater per hour through gill rakers.

size: Length: up to 2.3 m; Weight: 190 kg.
habitat: Outer reef slopes and channels across the Indo-Pacific.
funFact: The species is protogynous: individuals start female and many later transition to male.

habitat: Cold glacial lakes and arctic coastal waters around the circumpolar north.
funFact: Arctic char can overwinter under ice for months, feeding little until spring melt.

habitat: Cool canals and remnants of the Xochimilco lake system near Mexico City.
funFact: Axolotls remain in a larval state and can regrow limbs, spinal cord, and even parts of their heart.

lifeExpectancy: 4-6 years in the wild; longer in care.
habitat: Humid rainforests of Suriname and northern Brazil.
funFact: Alkaloid toxins from their ant diet can paralyze or kill predators many times their size.

habitat: Humid lowland forests from southern Mexico to Colombia.
funFact: When startled, it flashes red eyes and bright side stripes to disorient predators before leaping away.

habitat: Moist deciduous forests and mountain streams across central and southern Europe.
funFact: Glands behind the eyes ooze potent alkaloid toxins when the salamander is threatened.

size: Length: 10-15 cm; large females can exceed 20 cm.
habitat: Tropical forests, wetlands, and urban edges—native to Central/South America and invasive in Australia.
funFact: Huge parotoid glands exude bufotoxins that can fatally poison predators.

habitat: Woodland ponds and wetlands in eastern North America.
funFact: It cycles through aquatic larva, terrestrial bright-orange eft, then aquatic adult stages.

habitat: Clear, fast-flowing streams of the Appalachian and Ozark regions in the United States.
funFact: Loose, wrinkled skin increases surface area so it can absorb oxygen directly from the water.

size: Length: 1.2-1.8 m; Weight: up to 50 kg.
habitat: Cold, fast mountain streams in central and southern China.
funFact: It vocalizes with barks and hisses and secretes a milky substance that smells like pepper.

habitat: Moist tropical forests from Costa Rica to Ecuador, usually perched on leaves above streams.
funFact: Its translucent belly skin reveals organs and eggs, blending with sunlit leaves.

habitat: Prairies, woodlands, and ephemeral ponds across North America.
funFact: Larvae can develop enlarged heads and teeth to become cannibal morphs when ponds shrink.

habitat: Shallow ponds, rice paddies, and forest pools across northeastern China, Korea, and adjacent Russia.
funFact: When threatened it arches into an unken reflex, flashing a scarlet belly that warns of the mild toxins in its skin.

habitat: Karst caves and subterranean streams of the Dinaric Alps in Europe.
funFact: Blind olms can go more than 8 years without food thanks to a slow metabolism.

habitat: Slow, murky rivers and swamps of northern South America.
funFact: Females incubate eggs embedded in the skin of their backs until froglets emerge.

habitat: Permanent ponds and lakes throughout sub-Saharan Africa.
funFact: This species was once used for human pregnancy tests—injecting urine caused females to lay eggs.

size: Length: up to 24 cm (9.5 in); Weight: can reach 1.4 kg (3 lb).
habitat: Seasonal pans, savannas, and grasslands across southern and central Africa.
funFact: Males guard their tadpoles and even dig drainage channels to keep shrinking pools from drying out.

habitat: Humid lowland forests of Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama.
funFact: Females haul each tadpole to its own bromeliad and feed it unfertilized eggs.

habitat: Still ponds, irrigation canals, and slow streams on the Iberian Peninsula and in Morocco.
funFact: When attacked it arches its back so sharpened ribs pierce the skin and deliver toxins to a would-be predator.

size: Length: 8–10 cm, excluding the long toes.
lifeExpectancy: Estimated at around 6–8 years in the wild.
habitat: Rainforests of the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, and Borneo, gliding between canopy trees.
funFact: Extensive webbing between toes lets the frog glide more than 15 metres from tree to tree.

size: Body length: up to 32 cm; Weight: 3.3 kg.
habitat: Large, swift rivers in Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea.
funFact: They move rocks and plants to build riverbank pools for their eggs.

habitat: Rainforest hillsides along Colombia's Pacific coast.
funFact: One frog's skin produces enough batrachotoxin to stop the hearts of 10 humans.

habitat: Deciduous forests and vernal pools in eastern North America.
funFact: Embryos host symbiotic algae that supply oxygen inside the egg masses.

habitat: Wooded swamps, marshes, and vernal pools across eastern North America.
funFact: Male choruses reach over 90 decibels during early spring nights.

habitat: Coastal and foothill woodlands with slow-moving streams in California.
funFact: Skin glands secrete tetrodotoxin potent enough to deter most predators.

habitat: Moist leaf litter and soils of South American tropical forests.
funFact: Mothers grow nutrient-rich skin that hatchlings eat in rotating shifts.

size: Body length: 9-20 cm; Weight: up to 0.5 kg.
habitat: Ponds, marshes, and slow-moving waters across eastern North America and introduced regions worldwide.
funFact: Its deep "jug-o-rum" call can be heard over a kilometer across summer wetlands.

habitat: Mountain cloud forests of central Panama along fast streams.
funFact: Besides calls, they communicate with semaphore-like hand waves in noisy streams.

habitat: Gardens, forests, and wetlands across Europe and parts of Asia.
funFact: Parotoid glands exude bufotoxin, and the toad inflates its body to appear larger.

habitat: Arid grasslands, oak savannas, and temporary rain pools of California and Baja California.
funFact: A hardened black spur on each hind foot lets it burrow backward into the soil, where it waits out drought until desert rains arrive.

habitat: Boreal forests, bogs, and tundra edges across North America.
funFact: Wood frogs can freeze up to 65% of their body water and resume activity after thawing.

habitat: Moist meadows, woodlands, and garden ponds across Europe and parts of Asia.
funFact: These adaptable frogs hibernate buried in mud or leaf litter and can reabsorb oxygen through their skin while dormant underwater.

habitat: Dry forests and savannas on the Indonesian islands of Komodo, Rinca, Flores, and Gili Motang.
funFact: Komodo dragons possess mildly venomous saliva that lowers prey blood pressure.

habitat: Tropical and subtropical seas worldwide, nesting on sandy beaches.
funFact: Adults graze seagrass beds, trimming them like lawnmowers to keep meadows healthy.

habitat: Humid forests of India, Southeast Asia, and southern China.
funFact: It is the world's longest venomous snake and constructs a leaf nest to guard its eggs.

habitat: Desert scrub and rocky foothills in the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico.
funFact: Venom flows along grooved teeth and helps subdue prey after a crushing bite.

habitat: Rivers, lakes, and wetlands throughout sub-Saharan Africa.
funFact: Hatchlings chirp inside the eggs, prompting mothers to excavate the nest and carry them to water.

habitat: Volcanic highlands and arid lowlands across the Galápagos Islands.
funFact: Individuals help disperse seeds over kilometers, reshaping island plant communities.

habitat: Arid woodlands, savanna, and deserts of central Australia.
funFact: They darken and flare their spiky 'beard' to signal dominance or absorb heat.

habitat: Open oceans worldwide, nesting on tropical beaches.
funFact: A flexible shell and insulating fat let leatherbacks dive beyond 1,000 m into cold depths.

habitat: Freshwater swamps, marshes, and slow rivers of the southeastern United States.
funFact: Alligators build 'gator holes' that provide refuge for other animals during droughts.

habitat: Tropical woodlands of northern Australia and southern New Guinea.
funFact: When threatened it unfurls a 30 cm frill, hisses, and stands upright to look larger.

habitat: Coastal rainforests and plantations of Madagascar.
funFact: They shift colors in seconds to signal mood, temperature, or dominance.

habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and forest edges of West and Central Africa.
funFact: When alarmed they coil into a tight ball with head tucked safely inside.

habitat: Deserts, grasslands, and rocky canyons of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico.
funFact: Interlocking keratin segments on the tail vibrate up to 90 times per second to issue a warning buzz.

habitat: Dry shrublands and coastal forests on Grand Cayman Island.
funFact: Once near extinction, intensive conservation bred hundreds for release back into the wild.

habitat: Sandy deserts and scrub of central Australia.
funFact: Capillary channels between its scales wick dew and rain straight to its mouth.

habitat: Tropical forests, savannas, and semi-arid regions from Mexico to Argentina.
funFact: Heat-sensing pits along the lips help locate warm-blooded prey at night.

size: Length: 5-6 m; Weight: up to 250 kg.
habitat: Swamps, slow rivers, and flooded forests of the Amazon and Orinoco basins.
funFact: Females can give birth to litters of live young that each measure nearly a meter long.

size: Length: 70-120 cm; Weight: up to 12 kg.
habitat: Rocky coasts of the Galápagos Islands.
funFact: They dive into chilly surf to graze algae, then expel salt by sneezing crystals from nasal glands.

habitat: Rainforests, cliffs, and urban buildings across Southeast Asia.
funFact: It delivers forceful bites and calls 'to-kay!' loudly each night.

size: Carapace length: 0.9-1.1 m (3-3.5 ft); Weight: 135-180 kg (300-400 lb).
habitat: Warm temperate and subtropical oceans, nesting on sandy beaches worldwide.
funFact: Adults migrate thousands of kilometres between feeding grounds and the natal beaches where females return to lay eggs.

size: Shell length: 40-80 cm; Weight: up to 80 kg.
habitat: Deep rivers, swamps, and oxbow lakes of the southeastern United States.
funFact: A worm-like lure on its tongue wiggles to entice fish into its powerful jaws.

habitat: Savannas, scrub, and rocky outcrops across sub-Saharan Africa.
funFact: The black mamba can raise a third of its body and strike repeatedly with fast-acting neurotoxic venom.

habitat: Moist forests, fields, and meadows in eastern North America.
funFact: A hinged plastron lets box turtles seal themselves completely inside their shell.

habitat: Sandy deserts and shrublands of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico.
funFact: It can squirt blood from the corners of its eyes to deter canid predators.

habitat: Lowland rainforests of New Guinea.
funFact: Its prehensile tail and long claws make it an agile climber in dense canopy.

size: Length: 1-2 m; Weight: up to 10 kg.
habitat: Humid forests and savannas of central and West Africa.
funFact: It has the longest fangs of any venomous snake, measuring up to 5 cm.

habitat: Slow rivers, oxbow lakes, and flooded wetlands from Mexico to Brazil.
funFact: A bony ridge between the eyes forms the 'spectacles' that inspire its name, helping shade the eyes while it waits for fish.

habitat: Eucalypt forests and woodlands of eastern Australia.
funFact: They raid tree hollows for bird eggs and seal termites re-open nests used as warm incubators.

size: Length: 3-5 m; Weight: up to 90 kg.
habitat: Marshes, grasslands, and river valleys of Southeast Asia; invasive in Florida's Everglades.
funFact: Expandable jaws and flexible ribs allow it to swallow prey wider than its own body.

size: Length: 12-20 cm (5-8 in) including the tail.
habitat: Shrubs, tree trunks, and garden fences across the southeastern United States and Caribbean islands.
funFact: Males flash a vivid red dewlap and can shift from bright green to brown as they defend territories and communicate.

habitat: Near large lakes, reservoirs, and coasts across North America.
funFact: Pairs build tree nests that can weigh over a metric ton after years of reuse.

habitat: Cliffs, mountains, and urban skyscrapers on every continent except Antarctica.
funFact: Peregrines stoop on prey at speeds exceeding 320 km/h, making them the fastest animals alive.

habitat: Sea ice and frigid Antarctic waters.
funFact: Males incubate eggs on their feet for two months while fasting through polar night.

habitat: Tropical rainforests and river edges of Central and northern South America.
funFact: Pairs mate for life and scream loud contact calls to stay together above the canopy.

lifeExpectancy: 7 years in the wild; longer in captivity.
habitat: Deciduous forests, parks, and suburban neighborhoods in eastern North America.
funFact: Blue jays mimic hawk calls to warn flock mates or to scare competitors away from food.

size: Height: up to 1.5 m; Wingspan: 2.2-2.5 m.
habitat: Wetlands and riverine marshes in northeast Asia.
funFact: Elaborate courtship dances strengthen lifelong pair bonds.

habitat: Forests, deserts, parks, and city neighborhoods across the Americas.
funFact: Feather fringes along its wing edges allow near-silent flight as it ambushes prey.

size: Wingspan: about 2 m (6.5 ft); Weight: 3-5 kg (6.6-11 lb).
habitat: Coastal shorelines, estuaries, and barrier islands throughout the Americas.
funFact: It is the only pelican that plunge-dives from height, folding its wings to spear into the water after schooling fish.

habitat: Papyrus swamps and freshwater marshes of East Africa.
funFact: A massive shoe-shaped bill snaps shut with enough force to capture lungfish and baby crocodiles.

habitat: Open grasslands and savannas of sub-Saharan Africa.
funFact: Long legs deliver rapid, crushing kicks to subdue snakes on the ground.

habitat: Humid lowland and foothill forests from southern Mexico to northern Colombia.
funFact: Despite its rainbow bill, the toucan's beak is a lightweight honeycomb of keratin that allows agile tree-hopping.

habitat: Woodlands and gardens of eastern North America; winters in Central America.
funFact: They hover with wingbeats around 55 times per second and can fly backward.

habitat: Open savannas and deserts across Africa.
funFact: Ostriches sprint up to 70 km/h using 4 m strides.

habitat: Dense rainforests of New Guinea and northern Australia.
funFact: A dagger-like inner claw can deliver powerful kicks when the bird feels threatened.

size: Body length: 95-115 cm; Train up to 1.5 m; Weight: 4-6 kg.
habitat: Forests, farms, and villages across the Indian subcontinent.
funFact: Males fan iridescent tail trains covered in 'eyes' to court peahens.

habitat: The Southern Ocean, looping vast distances between subantarctic islands.
funFact: Their record wingspan lets them glide for hours without flapping.

habitat: Cliff colonies on islands and coasts of the North Atlantic.
funFact: Specialized tongue spines hold a dozen fish crosswise in the beak for chicks.

size: Height: about 60 cm; Wingspan: 1 m; Weight: 1.4-1.7 kg.
habitat: Coastal mangroves, mudflats, and estuaries from northern South America to the Caribbean.
funFact: They fly in V-shaped flocks that flash crimson in the sunset as they return to communal roosts.

habitat: Arctic tundra across North America, Europe, and Asia.
funFact: Feathered legs and toes protect against sub-zero winds on the tundra.

size: Length: 95-120 cm; Wingspan: around 1.5 m; Weight: 2-4 kg.
habitat: Tropical evergreen forests from India to Indonesia.
funFact: During nesting, the female seals herself inside a tree cavity with mud, leaving a slot for food deliveries.

habitat: Moist forests of southeastern Australia.
funFact: Males mimic camera shutters, car alarms, and chainsaws during courtship displays.

habitat: Mountains, forests, tundra, and deserts across the Northern Hemisphere.
funFact: Ravens solve puzzles, use tools, and engage in aerial acrobatics for play.

lifeExpectancy: Around 30 years in the wild, longer in captivity.
habitat: Mountains, cliffs, and open uplands across Eurasia, North America, and North Africa.
funFact: Monogamous pairs reuse massive cliffside eyries for generations, adding new branches each breeding season.

habitat: Tropical rainforests from southern Mexico to northern Argentina.
funFact: Harpy talons rival a grizzly bear's claws and can snatch monkeys from trees.

habitat: Lakes, slow rivers, and ornamental ponds across Europe and introduced regions worldwide.
funFact: Pairs form lifelong bonds and arch their necks to display heart-shaped courtship poses.

habitat: Clean streams, ponds, and rivers across Europe, Africa, and Asia.
funFact: They close a transparent third eyelid to see clearly underwater as they dive.

size: Height: 85-115 cm; Wingspan: up to 1.8 m.
habitat: Tree-lined wetlands and marshes of the southeastern United States, Central America, and northern South America.
funFact: They feed by touch, snapping their half-open bills shut in milliseconds when fish brush past.

size: Length: about 25 cm (10 in); Weight: 77-85 g (2.7-3 oz).
lifeExpectancy: Typically 6 years in the wild, with records over a decade.
habitat: Forest edges, suburban lawns, and parklands across most of North America.
funFact: Robins run, stop, and tilt their heads to locate earthworms, and their dawn chorus is one of the earliest songs of spring.

size: Height: about 60 cm (24 in); Wingspan: roughly 1 m (3 ft).
lifeExpectancy: Up to 16 years in the wild.
habitat: Coastal marshes, estuaries, mangroves, and freshwater wetlands throughout the Americas.
funFact: It stirs prey with bright yellow feet, shuffling through the shallows before stabbing fish and crustaceans.

habitat: Grasslands, farmlands, and open woodlands worldwide.
funFact: A heart-shaped facial disc funnels faint sounds to its asymmetrical ears for pinpoint hunting.
